title: How to Make a Pineapple Infused Vodka Martini

steps.headline: To create your pineapple infused vodka, start with going to your local package store and purchasing your alcohol.
steps.description: You really shouldn't procure cheap vodka, and you certainly shouldn't dole out your dollars for the expensive stuff either. Go with a middle of the road priced vodka.

steps.headline: Pick yourself out some very nice pineapples.
steps.description: One or two (depending on size) will do. Also while there, pick up a jar with a lid. A canning jar is a great idea for this. How many jars you need depends on how much of this liquid libation you intend to create. If you have a 750 ml (25 oz) bottle, two one quart jars should get the job done. If you've got your hands on a fifth, then you're probably going to need three possibly four jars.

steps.headline: Wash and rinse the jars and allow to air dry.
steps.description: For best results, run the jars and lids in the dishwasher.

steps.headline: Get out the cutting board and a sharp knife.
steps.description: Cut off the top and bottom of the pineapple. Stand the pineapple up on one end and use the knife to shear off the outer skin from the sides. Make sure to remove all of the skin and eyes from the pineapple. Cut the pineapple into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) slices similar to a loaf of bread. There is no need to core the pineapple. Lay each slice flat and cut into quarters.

steps.headline: Layer the pineapple slices in the jars so that the vodka will be able to flow around each piece.
steps.description: Fill the jar by pouring the "water of life" over the fruit. Allow to sit in a cool, dark place for ten days.

steps.headline: Since we didn't add sugar to the vodka, we need to make a simple syrup to sweeten the martini (In case the pineapple wasn't sweet enough.
steps.description: Taste your now infused vodka, if it is already pretty sweet, you can omit this step.) To make a simple syrup, put two cups of water on the stove and add two cups of sugar until dissolved.

steps.headline: Fill a cocktail glass with ice and water.
steps.description: Fill a shaker with ice. Pour about 5 1/2 oz. (155 ml) of pineapple infused vodka in the shaker and shake it until frost forms on the outside of the tin. Pour out the ice/water from the cocktail glass, strain the martini into the cocktail glass. Garnish with a pineapple slice.

text: To create your pineapple infused vodka, start with going to your local package store and purchasing your alcohol. You really shouldn't procure cheap vodka, and you certainly shouldn't dole out your dollars for the expensive stuff either. Go with a middle of the road priced vodka. Pick yourself out some very nice pineapples. One or two (depending on size) will do. Also while there, pick up a jar with a lid. A canning jar is a great idea for this. How many jars you need depends on how much of this liquid libation you intend to create. If you have a 750 ml (25 oz) bottle, two one quart jars should get the job done. If you've got your hands on a fifth, then you're probably going to need three possibly four jars. Wash and rinse the jars and allow to air dry. For best results, run the jars and lids in the dishwasher. Get out the cutting board and a sharp knife. Cut off the top and bottom of the pineapple. Stand the pineapple up on one end and use the knife to shear off the outer skin from the sides. Make sure to remove all of the skin and eyes from the pineapple. Cut the pineapple into ⁄2 inch (1.3 cm) slices similar to a loaf of bread. There is no need to core the pineapple. Lay each slice flat and cut into quarters. Layer the pineapple slices in the jars so that the vodka will be able to flow around each piece. Fill the jar by pouring the "water of life" over the fruit. Allow to sit in a cool, dark place for ten days. On to the martini part.  Since we didn't add sugar to the vodka, we need to make a simple syrup to sweeten the martini (In case the pineapple wasn't sweet enough. Taste your now infused vodka, if it is already pretty sweet, you can omit this step.) To make a simple syrup, put two cups of water on the stove and add two cups of sugar until dissolved. Fill a cocktail glass with ice and water. Fill a shaker with ice. Pour about 5 1/2 oz. (155 ml) of pineapple infused vodka in the shaker and shake it until frost forms on the outside of the tin. Pour out the ice/water from the cocktail glass, strain the martini into the cocktail glass. Garnish with a pineapple slice.
